title: Simple circuits - rank the numbers of lit bulbs

content.description: The circuit shown in the figure consists of a battery, three switches, and three lightbulbs. A student examines the circuit using the following configurations of switch settings.
content.question: Switch <math alttext="S sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>Switch <math alttext="S sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>Switch <math alttext="S sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></math>Configuration <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>OpenClosedClosedConfiguration <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>ClosedOpenClosedConfiguration <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>ClosedClosedOpenFor each configuration, the student counts the number <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> of lighted bulbs. Which of the following correctly compares the numbers <math alttext="N sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="N sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="N sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> for the three switch configurations?

choices.label: <math alttext="N sub 1, equals N sub 2, which equals N sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="N sub 1, is greater than N sub 2, which is greater than N sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="N sub 2, is greater than N sub 1, which equals N sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="N sub 2, is greater than N sub 3, which is greater than N sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="N sub 2, is greater than N sub 3, which is greater than N sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
